Comment: In Alito's dissent for Obergefell v. Hodges:  "Invoking Glucksberg, in which the Court stated the Due Process Clause protects only rights and liberties that are "deeply rooted in this Nation's history and tradition", Alito claimed any "right" to same-sex marriage would not meet this definition; he chided the justices in the majority for going against judicial precedent and long-held tradition."  The issue here with Alito's interpretation, as noted by many others, is that what is "deeply rooted in the Nation's history" is incredibly up to interpretation. Prior to the 1950's, interracial marriage was uncommon in the country. Does this then mean that interracial marriage isn't a protected right and the decision reached in Loving v. Virginia was wrong? What about Zablocki v. Redhail or Turner v. Safely? They were also rulings on marriage that one could argue didn't have "deeply roots in the Nation's history". Are those decisions wrong as well?   As far as judicial precedent, marriage itself has been consistently upheld as a protected right under the Due Process Clause of the 14th Amendment, as seen by the court cases I just mentioned. SCOTUS has consistently upheld the constitutional right to interracial marriage and has struck down laws prohibiting marriage based on past actions such as child support and imprisonment, all of which set a heavy precedent that marriage is a protected right under the Due Process Clause. Yet suddenly, when the marriage is between two individuals of the same sex, that's when the majority is going "against judicial precedent".  Simply put, this is just one example where you could argue that Alito has tried to twist the law the fit what he believes it should be and not what is actually Constitutional.
